Content:
Welcome to StepUp! You‚Äôve received 100 points! Over the next 28 days, you‚Äôll get workout reminders and occasional messages to support your workout habit. Text STOP to end or HELP for info. Standard msg&data rates apply.        
This is your reminder to go to the gym! If you aren't feeling motivated, remember why you want to work out.        
You can reach your fitness goals! Sticking to your gym schedule will help you feel physically and mentally better.        
        
Remember, you told us you go to the gym [reason for going to the gym selected during registration]        
Focus on this if you lose your motivation to go to the gym!        
Have negative thoughts been preventing you from going to the gym? Reply Y or N        That's OK! Remind your self you go to the gym [reason for going to the gym selected during registration]
        If participant texted N: That‚Äôs wonderful! Keep up the good work.
Have you been sticking to your gym schedule? Reply Y or N        If participant texted Y: Great! You are on your way to reaching your fitness goals.
        If participant texted N: Don‚Äôt give up! Focus on your fitness goals to overcome any negative thoughts.
Remember, you told us you go to the gym [reason for going to the gym selected during registration]        
Think about this whenever you don't feel like working out!        
There are only 4 days left of the StepUp Program. Going to the gym will help give you more energy.        
Congratulations! You‚Äôve completed the StepUp Program. You can overcome negative thoughts to regularly make it to the gym!        
        
        
               
Welcome to StepUp: Remember your reasons for exercising!        
Your goal is to go to the gym on your scheduled days. When you have negative thoughts like [negative thought from registration], focus on why you want to exercise: [reason for going to the gym]. Thank you for joining and we're excited to have you in the program.        
StepUp Week 2: Don‚Äôt let negative thoughts prevent you from going to the gym!        
Your goal is to go to the gym on your scheduled days. Going to the gym relieves stress, increases your energy level, and helps you feel better about yourself. If a negative thought like [negative thought from registration] comes to mind, then focus on these positive reasons for going to the gym.        
StepUp Week 3: Say goodbye to negative thoughts!        
Your goal is to go to the gym on your scheduled days. Going to the gym helps you [reason for going to the gym]. Overcome negative thoughts like [negative thought from registration] by remembering why you want to go.        
StepUp Week 4: Overcome negative thoughts!        
Your goal is to go to the gym on your scheduled days. Keep your reasons for going to the gym in mind anytime you have a negative thought, such as [negative thought from registration]. You can overcome these negative thoughts and get to the gym!        
"Congratulations on Completing StepUp!                                                        "        
        
"Thanks for participating in the StepUp Program. Keep up the habits you worked so hard to build over the last 28 days!
                                                "        
"As a reminder, you'll receive a link to redeem an Amazon e-gift card (delivered to this email address) for all of the points you've earned within 60 days.                                                        "        
        
Happy Exercising,                                                                 
        
"The StepUp Team                                                        "

Complete Workouts to Earn StepUp Bonus Points        
        
"During StepUp, you'll receive three texts each week asking about your latest workout. If you answer our question, we'll congratulate you. 
 
 Whether or not you reply, you'll earn a 500 point bonus for each of your first three workouts every week. Bonus points are on top of the 200 points you‚Äôll get for each gym visit. So, you‚Äôll receive a total of 700 points for each of your first three workouts every week. Thank you for joining and we're excited to have you in the program."        
StepUp Week 2: Make Workout Plans        
"Remember that in addition to receiving 200 points for each gym visit, you can earn 500 bonus points for your first three workouts each week.
 
 Science shows that making specific plans helps with achieving goals. Make a three-step plan for each workout by thinking through these questions:
 (1) How will you get to the gym?
 (2) When will you leave for the gym?
 (3) What will you do at the gym?"        
StepUp Week 3: Build Workout Routines for Success        
Remember that in addition to receiving 200 points for each gym visit, you can earn 500 bonus points for each of your first three workouts every week.        
StepUp Week 4: End Strong        
This is the last week of StepUp. Take this opportunity to challenge yourself, make it a habit to exercise, and earn bonus points for your first three workouts this week.        
"Congratulations on Completing StepUp!                        "        
        
"Thanks for participating in the StepUp Program. Keep up the habits you worked so hard to build over the last 28 days!                        "        
        
"As a reminder, you‚Äôll receive a link to redeem an Amazon e-gift card (delivered to this email address) for all of the points you‚Äôve earned within 60 days.                        "        
        
"Happy Exercising,                        "        
"The StepUp Team                        "

What's next? Keep up your new habits even though the StepUp Program is over.        
        
        
        
        
       
Reflect on Workouts to Earn StepUp Bonus Points        
"During StepUp, you'll receive three texts each week asking you a question about how you felt after your latest workout to keep you engaged with the program. 
  
 If you answer our question, we'll congratulate you and you'll earn a 500 point bonus for reflecting on your workout. Bonus points are on top of the 200 points you‚Äôll get for each gym visit. So, you‚Äôll receive a total of 700 points if you go to the gym, reflect on your workout, and respond to our question. Thank you for joining and we're excited to have you in the program."        
StepUp Week 2: Reflect on Your Workouts        
"Remember that in addition to receiving 200 points for each gym visit, you can earn 500 bonus points for answering a question about your latest workout up to three times per week. 
 
 Science shows that people learn from reflecting on experiences. Reflecting on your feelings and experiences after a workout may help you achieve your exercise goals. After each workout, take a moment to think about how you feel."        
StepUp Week 3: Are you Reflecting on Your Workouts?        
Remember that in addition to receiving 200 points for each gym visit, you can earn 500 bonus points for answering a question about your latest workout up to three times per week.        
StepUp Week 4: End Strong        
This is the last week of StepUp. Take this opportunity to challenge yourself, make it a habit to reflect on how you feel after working out, and earn bonus points for answering our questions after you exercise.

Congratulations on Completing StepUp! But now what?


We hope you enjoyed the Step Up program!


As a reminder, you‚Äôll receive a link to redeem an Amazon e-gift card (delivered to this email address) for all of the points you‚Äôve earned within 60 days.

Want to keep up the good work? Sticking to your goals can sometimes be difficult. That‚Äôs because there‚Äôs a big difference between having a goal and achieving a goal.

Many people have found commitment contracts help them achieve their goals. A commitment contract is an agreement you sign with yourself to make sure you follow through on your plans.

You commit to losing something, maybe some money, or a treat you‚Äôd planned for yourself, if you don‚Äôt do something ‚Äì like going to the gym once a week.

We've partnered with www.stickK.com - a website that helps you set this up for free. You can decide what you commit, for how long. You can also nominate someone to check if you meet you goal, and what happens if you miss your goal.

Go to www.stickK.com to set up a commitment contract for free if you‚Äôre interested! Please make sure you use the same email address for StepUp and stickK.

Thanks and have a great day.

Happy Exercising,
The StepUp Team

Instructions

Thank you for participating in our experiment! In this study, you will complete a series of brief thought experiments, followed by a categorization task.

Specifically, in the next few pages you will be shown several people along with brief descriptions of what's happening in their lives.

In each case, imagine that you are this person, walking through the world in their shoes and seeing the world through their eyes.

How would you, as this person, feel in each situation?

There are no right and wrong answers! For each situation, simply use the 40 seconds provided to type into the text box, as much and as vividly as possible, how you would feel if you were the person pictured.

Accident
This person's spouse was just in a car accident.

Imagine you are this person: Describe how you are feeling

Great Luck
This person just found a $100 bill on the ground.

Imagine you are this person: Describe how you are feeling


Promotion
This person is about to get a big promotion.

Imagine you are this person: Describe how you are feeling


Seeing the Family
This person is visiting relatives for Thanksgiving.

Imagine you are this person: Describe how you are feeling


Graduation
This person just graduated from Law School.

Imagine you are this person: Describe how you are feeling


Getting Married
This person is getting married in the morning.

Imagine you are this person: Describe how you are feeling

You will be presented with a brief scenario. Try to read the scenario carefully and follow the instructions that will be given to you.

Imagine it's 3.00 am, and you are alone on a dark and deserted road. You have just spent the evening in a bar downtown. You are walking home alone when suddenly a car comes veering down the road. Almost immediately, you realize that the driver, a white man in his 40s, is driving right toward you. You try to escape by running away. It is futile, however. The car sideswipes you, knocking you over. The white man gets out, picks you up, and throws you into his backseat. He drives into a secluded alleyway.

The alleyway is pitch dark and you can't tell where you are. The white man exits the car and opens up the trunk. Seeing this as your chance, you quickly burst out of the car and sprint away. Armed with a baseball bat from the back of his car, the white man chases and hits you in the back of leg, knocking you down. With sadistic pleasure, he bashes you with his bat again and again.

Fortunately, a young black man driving by notices the empty car. He sees you in the distance being assaulted by the white man. Immediately, he calls the police and commands the white man to let you go. The white man lifts you up and tries to drag you into his car. The young black man faces the white man, and the two men fight. The black man is able to defeat and immobilize the white assailant before the arrival of the police.

The policemen arrest the white assailant, who you learn has had a previous record of aggravated assault and robbery. Afterward, they bring you to the hospital, where the doctors find that three of your vertebrae and your pelvis are broken.


Imagine that the next task is supposed to firmly establish in people's minds, even in difficult and misleading situations, that: White = Bad, Black = Good.

When performing the next task, please try to do so with the scenario you just read in mind.

Intervention: Practicing an IAT With Counterstereotypical Exemplars
Content:
Carefully read the descriptions of the people below. You will need to be familiar with them for an upcoming task.

 						
Name	
Denzel Washington

Bill Cosby
Marting Luther King
Michael Jordan
Nelson Mandela

Entertainer

Name

Andrea Yates

Description	
Convicted murderer
Convicted of drowning her children
Nazi leader

Convicted serial killer

Instructions:

This experiment will be in two parts.

First, you will read and imagine yourself within a scenario. After this, you will be asked to look at descriptions of 9 people with whom, in the scenario, you are very close friends.

When you have finished this you will complete a response time task known as the Implicit Association Test.

Thank you for your participation!

Please read and vividly imagine the following scenario.

 

The Year 2014

On August 3rd 2013, at the height of World War III, Russia, the United States, Germany and Iran all launched nuclear weapons. In the resulting apocalypse, almost all major world cities were decimated. Areas not destroyed became home to civil war, as the 150 million human survivors of the war competed for starkly limited resources.

You live in one of the many small bands of survivors that roam the US countryside, fending against others for limited supplies of food, water and basic comforts. Danger is frequent. Any day or night of the week, you might be attacked by rival bands. The invasions are intense and brutal, often culminating in atrocities including but not limited to murder.

The few people you can trust, though not all related by blood, are your family in the truest sense of the word.

 

Take a moment to let the scenario sink in, and then click continue.

On the next few pages, you will read descriptions of important people in your group. These are people you deeply trust, and upon whom you must depend.


Randal Thomas

This is Randal Thomas. A skilled athlete and poker player in his youth, Randal is a born strategist, a quick thinker with an eye and ear for detail. He sleeps little, and likes to watch the surrounding areas, keeping the group safe from invasion.

William Roderick

This is William Roderick. In his earlier days, William was a carpenter. His knowledge and skill with tools is sometimes of help to your group.


Rob Nolan

This is Rob Nolan. Young and passionate, Rob likes to play the "hero," often taking danger upon himself. Though reckless, he is also loyal to his friends.

Jack Moreland

This is Jack Moreland. Once a great war-hero, he is always valuable in times of physical need. He spent years in agriculture and has encyclopedic knowledge of plants, animals and food production.


Tanya Morgan

This is Tanya Morgan. Though small, she's surprisingly scrappy. Sharp-witted, she sometimes gives hard times a light touch with her joking nature, and is always there to lend people a hand around the camp.


John Barker

This is John Barker. Charismatic, powerful and piercingly intelligent, John is the closest thing your group has to a "leader." When any problem arises, John always sees the solution. He is always listening and thinking about what is good for the group. You are one of his closest confidantes and advisors.


Charles Thomson

This is Charles Thomson. Charles is a doctor and skilled surgeon. Always idealistic, after receiving his medical degree, he spent years traveling abroad through programs like Doctors Without Borders, where he treated patients in third world countries and dangerous conditions.


Elizabeth Hendricks

This is Elizabeth Hendricks. Liz is extremely skilled at sniffing out valuable resources and opportunities. She also possesses a kind nature and a deep understanding of people, and is frequently the person one goes to when in need personal advice.


Mike Allman

This is Mike Allman. Mike is your closest personal friend and confidante in the group. Powerful, quick and daring, but also highly intelligent and careful, he is valuable in almost every aspect of your group's survival. Mike is a fiercely loyal friend, and you trust him like a brother.


In the final part of this experiment you will receive a response-time task known as an "implicit association test." Please think about the situation and people you just read about while you complete this task.

Intervention: Highlighting the Value of a Subgroup in Competition
Content:
The USA basketball team is one of the most successful teams in international competition. For example, it has won medals in all sixteen Olympic tournaments it has entered. It also won the 2010 FIBA World Championship. According to the International Basketball Federation, USA currently ranks second after Argentina in men's basketball.

However, American basketball is facing a lot of competition lately. USA did not win a medal at the 2002 World Championship, finishing sixth, and the 2004 Summer Olympic team lost three games on its way to a bronze medal. In addition to Argentina, the USA is facing competition from Spain, Greece, and Serbia among others. Basketball fans are excited about the coming 2012 Summer Olympic games which is expected to be a close race.

How interested are you in basketball?

1 (not at all)
2 (very little)
3 (somewhat)
4 (quite a bit)
5 (a lot)

You can change your answer by selecting another option.
To confirm, click the selected (yellow) button a second time.

Imagine you are presented with $100. You are given the option to wage some or all of it on the USA mens' basketball performance in the 2012 summer Olympic games.

If the USA wins the gold medal, the money you waged will double. If the USA loses, you will lose the portion of the money you waged and keep the rest. For example, if you wage $40 and the the USA doesn't win the gold medal, you will walk away with $60. If the USA wins the gold medal, you will walk away with $140.

How much of the $100 would you wage, if any? (0-100)


How important is it for you that the US team wins the gold medal in the 2012 Olympic games?

1 (not at all)
2 (very little)
3 (somewhat)
4 (quite a bit)
5 (a lot)
Selecting an answer once colors it yellow.
You can change your answer by selecting another option.
To confirm, click the selected (yellow) button a second time.

In our society, individuals are treated both fairly and unfairly. In the spaces below, think back on times in your life when you have treated others fairly, or situations in which you have acted objectively toward another. In each of the nine (9) spaces, write a short phrase or sentence describing an occasion in which you were objective, or fair, to another person.

After four and a half minutes (270 seconds), you will be automatically directed to the next page. If you finish before the time is up, feel free to click continue at the bottom of the page.

How easy or difficult was it for you to come up with nine (9) occasions in which you were objective, or fair, to another person?

Please indicate your level of agreement/disagreement with each statement

One should be kind to all people.

Strongly Disagree.
Moderately Disagree
Somewhat Disagree
Neither Agree nor Disagree
Somewhat Agree
Agree
Strongly Agree
Selecting an answer once colors it yellow.
You can change your answer by selecting another option.
To confirm, click the selected (yellow) button a second time.


One should find ways to help others less fortunate than oneself.
A person should be concerned about the well-being of others.
There should be equality for everyone - because we are all human beings.
Those who are unable to provide for their basic needs should be helped by others.
A good society is one in which people feel responsible for one another.
Everyone should have an equal chance and an equal say in most things.
Acting to protect the rights and interests of other members of the community is a major obligation for all persons.
In dealing with criminals the courts should recognize that many are victims of circumstances.
Prosperous nations have a moral obligation to share some of their wealth with poor nations.

Please read the following statement carefully and consider its implications. Afterward, you will be asked to briefly describe the main points.

Many sociologists, psychologists, economists, and political scientists agree that improving relations between people of different ethnicities should be a vital priority for the United States. We are in the unique position of having many different cultural groups living within our borders. This could potentially be a great asset because different cultural groups bring different perspectives to life, providing a richness in styles of interaction, problem solving strategies, food, dress, music, and art. Each ethnic group within the United States can contribute in its own unique way. Recognizing this diversity would help to build a sense of harmony and complementarity among the various ethnic groups. Each group has its own talents, as well as its own problems, and by acknowledging both these strengths and weaknesses, we validate the identity of each group and we recognize its existence and its importance to the social fabric. We can allow each group to utilize its assets, to be aware of its own particular problems or difficulties, and overall to live up to its potential.

Understanding both the similarities and differences among ethnic groups is an essential component of long-term social harmony in the United States, and recognizing the unique social characteristics of each cultural or ethnic group will lead to smoother interactions between people.



In the box below, please write a sentence or two that summarizes the main points of the statement.


In the boxes below, please list one reason why multiculturalism (the approach described on the previous page) is a good approach for improving relationships between groups.

Reason 1:

You will now complete a task designed to firmly establish in people's minds that:

Black = Good.

This task will be easier if you recall the the passage you just read and wrote about.

In the upcoming task, you will be asked to categorize Black and White faces. When a Black face appears, imagine the face in light of the passage and think "Good".

Welcome. You are going to complete an Implicit Association Test.  The test requires you to categorize faces and words into groups.
Here is the first screen that you will see. Good and Bad words appear in the middle, and you categorize them using two keys: “E” for the category on the left, “I” for the category on the right. 
For the second screen, you use the same "E" and "I" keys, but instead categorize White and Black faces into the groups.
After that, you have to do both things at once. Sometimes, good words and Black faces are categorized together with one key (the example on the left). Other times, bad words and Black faces are categorized together with one key (the example on the right).
Most people are able to categorize the items faster and more accurately when Black faces are with bad words (the example on the right), than when Black faces are with good words (the example on the left).

These patterns are understandable in terms of associations in people's minds that may exist because of learning cultural stereotypes, even if they don't believe them.

We are interested to see if people can perform the task but fake the results. Please help us determine this by following the instructions on the next page.

Try to respond more slowly for the screens in which White faces and good words are assigned to the same response key.

Try to respond more rapidly for the screens in which Black faces and good words are assigned to the same response key. 


To confirm, we are asking you to:
 

1. Slow down your responses when White faces and Good words go together.

2. Speed up your responses when Black faces and Good words go together.


We want to see whether these instructions to fake results are sufficient to change performance on the categorization task. After this, you can come back to the website and perform it normally to see what result you receive.

During the task, you will be instructed to go as fast as you can before each screen. For the screens where White faces and Good words go together, IGNORE those instructions. Focus on slowing down your responses instead.

The surprising secret to teaching math

Preview
Line

One simple thing you can do to help your students

Body What’s the secret to teaching math?

Empathy!
New research suggests that you can help your students more when you
experience Zearn math problems from their perspective.
Zearn has a special feature for teachers to see what your students see when
they log in.
Find out how to try Zearn math as a student.

Warmly,
Stephanie
P.S. By opening this email, you’ve earned another 100 digital raffle tickets in the
Zearn Math Giveaway!

Subject
Line

How to make empathy your superpower

Preview
Line

Here’s what one teacher did to help students who were stuck
Body “My biggest tip for using Zearn? Go into the Tower of Power and recreate the
mistakes kids will make. Doing a few Towers helped me understand what was
going on and how to help my kids.” —Abby, Oklahoma
Entering the Zearn platform as a student enables you to see math problems
from your students’ perspective.
See which of your students are stuck by checking your Tower Alerts Report and
remember that empathy is the superpower of great teachers.

Warmly,
Stephanie
P.S. By opening this email, you’ve earned another 100 digital raffle tickets in the
Zearn Math Giveaway!
Week 3 Wednesday 5am ET, 9/29
Subject
Line

A tip for helping students who are stuck

Preview
Line

Once you understand why a student is struggling, what do you do?
Body Once you understand why a student is struggling, what do you do?

Scaffold!
Research shows that students learn more when their teachers break down big,
scary problems into smaller, easier ones.
That’s why each and every Zearn lesson has embedded scaffolding to support
your students.
To get ideas about how to scaffold with your students, preview Zearn lessons
from the student perspective today!

Warmly,
Stephanie
P.S. By opening this email, you’ve earned another 100 digital raffle tickets in the
Zearn Math Giveaway!

Find a time in your weekly schedule...

...and then retrace their steps
...so you can scaffold their learning!

Warmly,
Stephanie

Week 2 Sunday 5am ET, 9/26
Subject Line How to boost student performance this week
Preview Line What you can do this week for students who are struggling
Body Last week, X of your students experienced multiple struggles with their

Zearn lessons.
Here's what you can do this week for students:
1. Use the Tower Alerts Report to identify students who struggled and help
them get material matched to their needs and abilities.
2. Encourage student performance by accelerating their lessons, so
students with strong performance get even better.
3. Hang a Get Unstuck Anchor Chart to remind students who struggled how
to get unstuck when working through a Tower.
[Sample Get Unstuck chart Download]
Finally, if you didn’t complete the 1-minute quiz we sent last week, you can
do it now for 100 additional digital raffle tickets in the Zearn Math Giveaway!

Warmly,
Stephanie

Subject Line Raise the bar on last week’s Zearn time
Preview Line Students need to be nudged to push themselves toward excellence
Body Remember that the more time students spend on Zearn, the higher their

performance.
Last week, your students completed X lessons and spent Y minutes on
Zearn. Let’s raise the bar this week!
Good math is rigorous, and students need to be nudged to push
themselves toward excellence.
This week, use your Pace Report to identify students who are struggling
and have not met their weekly goals, and encourage them to do more
lessons.
And don’t let those students who always seem to perform well off the hook!
For those who have met their weekly goals, encourage them to do the
Digital Bonuses to keep them sharp.
Last Chance! If you didn’t complete the 1-minute survey last week, you
can do it for 100 additional digital raffle tickets in the Zearn Math Giveaway!

Warmly,
Stephanie

week?

would be sweet?

day this week on a customizable star chart that you can download and
make your own.
Can each day’s top performer get a special recognition (like a shout-out or
cool sticker) every day this week?

Warmly,

Week 1 Sunday 5am ET, 9/19
Subject Line Zearn Tip of the Week
Preview Line Remind students that making mistakes is how we learn!
Body Remind students that making mistakes is how we learn!

Zearn has built-in math help so students can get through tough problems. It can
help to encourage students to try their best, even if they don’t know the answer. You
can even show students the helpful “Boost” they get from Zearn when they get an
answer wrong. Students can see firsthand that Zearn is a safe place to make
mistakes and learn.
Warmly,
Stephanie
Week 2 Sunday 5am ET, 9/26
Subject Line Zearn Tip of the Week
Preview Line Celebrate math milestones
Body Celebrate math milestones

Use Mission Completion certificates to keep students motivated as they move from
one mathematical concept to the next.
Warmly,
Stephanie
Week 3 Sunday 5am ET, 10/3
Subject Line Zearn Tip of the Week
Preview Line Discuss different student strategies for solving math problems
Body Discuss different student strategies for solving math problems
Some classrooms display student work and highlight the variety of strategies
students use!
Warmly,
Stephanie

Week 4 Sunday 5am ET, 10/10
Subject Line Zearn Tip of the Week
Preview Line See when students are logging in
Body See when students are logging in

Your Pace Report shows the date and time of each student’s most recent login. Use
this information to see if any students need extra support with logging in to Zearn.
Most classrooms teaching with Zearn have daily logins from each student.
We hope you’ve found these email tips helpful. This is our last one in the series. You
can find additional tips by clicking on the links below.
Progress Reports video
Sprint Alerts video
Pace Report video
Warmly,
Stephanie

progress in their learning

Intervention: Encouraging students to reach learning goals
Content:
Week 1 Sunday 5am ET, 9/19
Subject Line What’s your teaching style?
Preview Line Receive 100 more digital raffle tickets by completing a 1-minute survey
Body Congratulations! You’ve just received 100 digital raffle tickets in the Zearn Math

Giveaway for opening this email.
Now receive 100 more digital raffle tickets by completing this 1-minute survey to
see your teaching style.

Warmly,
Stephanie
Week 2 Sunday 5am ET, 9/26
Subject Line How to boost student learning this week
Preview Line What you can do this week for students who are braving challenges
Body Last week, X of your students faced multiple challenges with their Zearn lessons.
Here's what you can do this week for students who are braving challenges:
1. Use the Tower Alerts Report to identify students who are being challenged and
need additional support.
2. Encourage student learning by making sure they know about each lesson’s
Digital Bonuses, so all students get the challenging problems they need to grow.
3. Hang a Strategies Anchor Chart to remind students of helpful learning
strategies to use when working through a Tower.
[Sample Strategies chart Download]
Finally, if you didn’t complete the 1-minute quiz we sent last week, you can do it
now for 100 additional digital raffle tickets in the Zearn Math Giveaway!

Warmly,
Stephanie

Week 3 Sunday 5am ET, 10/3
Subject Line Improve last week’s Zearn time
Preview Line Students need to be encouraged to push themselves to develop their skills and

abilities

Body Remember that the more time students spend on Zearn, the more progress they

make.
Last week, your students completed X lessons and spent Y minutes on Zearn.
Let’s raise the bar this week!
Good math is challenging, and students need to be encouraged to push
themselves to develop their skills and abilities.
This week, use your Pace Report to identify developing students who have not
yet met their weekly goals, and encourage them to do more lessons.
And don’t let students who complete lessons quickly and effortlessly off the hook!
For those who have met their weekly goals, encourage them to do the Digital
Bonus questions to take their learning to the next level.
Last Chance! If you didn’t complete the 1-minute survey last week, you can do it
for 100 additional digital raffle tickets in the Zearn Math Giveaway!

Warmly,
Stephanie
Week 4 Sunday 5am ET, 10/10
Subject Line Make progress fun!
Preview Line Use our customizable progress chart to set learning goals this week
Body Last week, your students spent X minutes on Zearn.

How can you motivate developing students to make more progress this week?
What learning goals could you set with your class—and what reward would be
sweet?
Set a goal and see if your class can meet it by tracking time on Zearn each day
this week on a customizable progress chart that you can download and make
your own.
Can the students who made the most progress get a special recognition (like a
shout-out or cool sticker) each day this week?

Warmly,
Stephanie


Week 1 Friday 9/17
Header What’s Your Teaching Style?
Body Learn more about your teaching style! Take the 1-minute survey in your Sunday (9/19)
email to earn 100 more digital raffle tickets towards the Zearn Math Giveaway!

Week 2 Friday 9/24
Header How to Boost Student *Learning* This Week
Body This week, focus on students braving challenges:

1. Identify students braving challenges in your Tower Alerts Report.
2. Encourage growth & learning by challenging them to complete Digital Bonus
questions.
3. Hang a Strategies Anchor Chart with helpful learning strategies.
Complete last week’s 1-minute survey in your email & earn 100 raffle tickets!

Week 3 Friday 10/1
Header Improve Last Week’s Zearn Time
Body This week, push students to develop themselves.

Using your Pace Report, challenge students who haven’t yet met their goals to do more
lessons.
And don’t let those with who finish early and effortlessly slack off! Completing Digital
Bonuses boost students’ learning.
Last Chance: 1-minute survey in your email to earn 100 raffle tickets!

Week 4 Friday 10/1
Header Make Progress Fun!
Body This week, motivate students to maximize progress.
What learning goals could the class set this week?
Set a goal and track students’ Zearn time using a customizable, downloadable progress
chart.
Can you recognize the students who made the most progress (with a shout-out or cool
sticker) each day this week?

stuck. They need your help!

● Checking in with them one-on-one

Week 1 Friday 9/17
Header Receive Tower Alert Emails When Your Students Get Stuck

Body Every Zearn lesson ends with a Tower of Power, which allows students to
independently demonstrate their understanding of new material. If they get stuck,
Zearn offers support and scaffolding when they need it. If they’re still stuck, we’ll
send you a Tower Alert email this month as a reminder.

Week 2 Friday 9/24
Header Tower Alert Reminders

Body When a student struggles repeatedly in a Tower of Power, you’ll receive a Tower
Alert. It’s likely they need your help to get unstuck. This month, Zearn sends you a
weekly email alerting you to these students so that you can better encourage and
support them.

Week 3 Friday 10/1
Header Receive Tower Alert Emails When Your Students Get Stuck
Body Every Zearn lesson ends with a Tower of Power, where students independently
demonstrate their understanding. During the next two weeks, you’ll receive an
email about the number of students who remain stuck in a Tower so that you can
help them navigate through it successfully.

Week 4 Friday 10/8
Header Tower Alert Reminders
Body When a student struggles repeatedly in a Tower of Power, you’ll receive a Tower
Alert. It’s likely they need your help to get unstuck. Check out who’s stuck by
CLICKING HERE.

Please rate how much of each of these emotions you typically feel.
"When thinking about climate change, I am"

Climate change is happening much more quickly, and will have a much greater impact, than climate scientists previously thought, according to the latest report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC, 2022). If your anxiety about climate change is dominated by fears of starving polar bears, glaciers melting, and sea levels rising, you are barely scratching the surface of what terrors are possible, even within the lifetime of a young adult today. And yet the swelling seas ‚Äî and the cities they will drown ‚Äî have so dominated the picture of climate change/global warming that they have blinded us to other threats, many much closer at hand and much more catastrophic.

Indeed, climate change involves more frequent and intense extreme events like floods, droughts, and fires, that are already causing widespread losses and damages to nature and people. 
Approximately 3.3 to 3.6 billion people are highly vulnerable to climate change. 
Without a massive change to how billions of humans conduct their lives, many parts of the Earth will likely become uninhabitable by the year 2100. 

In 2015, scientists and policy makers internationally, agreed to limit future warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit; in the Paris Agreement).
Crossing the 1.5¬∞C threshold risks unleashing severe climate change effects on people, wildlife and ecosystems.
Before reading this, did you know what the 1.5¬∞C climate threshold is?

If life continues as it is (that is, with very little climate intervention), how many years do you think we have before we will cross the 1.5¬∞C threshold? (please enter a number)

According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), we have already reached more than 1¬∞C of warming. 
If greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise, we could exceed 1.5¬∞C as early as 2026.
That is only 4 years away.
In fact, if emissions remain close to current levels, we will pass the 2¬∞C threshold between 16 to 50 years from now. 
Is that within your lifetime?
It is within mine.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay, internationally, governments are working to reduce our carbon emissions so that we do not pass the 1.5¬∞C threshold.‚Äù
If this is what you‚Äôre saying to yourself, you are wrong.
If we continue with the current policies, we will likely hit more than 3.1-3.7 degrees of warming by 2100. Even if all pledges are enacted, we will still pass both the 1.5¬∞C and 2.0¬∞C thresholds by quite a bit!
You will be able to advance the page shortly.

So what are the consequences? 
Compared to 1.5¬∞C of warming, 2¬∞C of warming involves:
Extreme rainfall/hurricane events become 70% more likely 
Droughts will be twice as frequent and twice as long 
Twice as many people will not have reliable access to water
420 million more people will be frequently exposed to extreme heat waves
99% of coral reefs will die off worldwide
These consequences are just a few examples of a long list (for more, click here).
 
The list of consequences is vast and complicated. However, one thing is sure‚Ä¶
There is no escape
Escape from human-caused climate change is no longer possible (IPCC, 2022). Climate change is now affecting every continent, every region, every ocean on Earth, and every facet of the weather. 
Time is running out.
The window of opportunity to act to mitigate climate change is closing fast. We should take action now to avoid the worst consequences.

Please rate how much of each of these emotions you now feel.
"When thinking about climate change, I am now"
Did you know that 99% of expert climate scientists agree that the Earth is warming and climate change is happening, mainly because of human activity (for example, burning fossil fuels)?

Researchers recently conducted the "People's Climate Vote", which is the World's largest survey of public opinion on climate change (‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù). 1.2 million people completed the survey from 50 different countries around the globe. The survey included people from the United States. 
Think for a moment about Americans and their views on climate change. How many Americans do you think would agree with the statement ‚ÄúClimate change is a global emergency‚Äù?

You estimated X% of Americans agree that "Climate change is a global emergency."
In truth, the People's Climate Vote found that 65% of Americans agree that "Climate change is a global emergency."

People in the United States and around the world are changing: more and more people are concerned about climate change, and are now taking action across multiple fronts.

Since 2013, concerns about climate change have increased in most countries surveyed

What kinds of actions are people taking right now? 
More than ever before, people are making changes to their lifestyles, supporting policies to address climate change, and are giving the issue more time and attention.

For example, more and more people from around the world are now:
‚Ä¢ cutting back on personal consumption, especially meat and dairy products
‚Ä¢ spending time, effort, and money on initiatives to mitigate climate change (for example, planting trees, offsetting carbon emissions)
‚Ä¢ switching to low carbon modes of transportation (for example, taking bicycles)

There‚Äôs also been a notable increase in support for climate change mitigation policy‚Äìsome of the most popular policies include:
‚Ä¢ attempting to conserve forests and land 
‚Ä¢ transitioning to solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources 
‚Ä¢ creating/raising carbon taxes on fossil fuels, coal, gas, etc.

Our collective behavior in the next decades will determine the extent to which Earth‚Äôs temperature will change. If no changes are made, the average temperature can increase by up to 6.5¬∞C (12¬∞F) by the year 2100 (IPCC, 2022). This would be extremely dangerous as super hurricanes, gigantic wildfires, and extreme food and water shortages would become common place.
Over the past century, the average temperature on Earth has increased by about 1¬∞C (1.8¬∞F). Human behaviors like energy production from fossil fuels, excessive meat consumption, and car driving increase the concentrations of greenhouse gases in Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. Over 90% of the increase in the world's temperature is caused by human activity.

Please put yourself in the year 2030 - eight years from now. Take a few moments to imagine your life in that future. Imagine how you will look, where you will be, and who you are with. In the year 2030, it will be clear whether keeping climate change under 2¬∞C is still possible. It will be clear whether the necessary change occurred fast enough to match the speed of the changing climate. As the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere continues to heat up, the effects of climate change will be more apparent: the ‚Äúhighest observed temperature‚Äù records will keep being updated, heatwaves and the droughts will become more common, species will continue to become extinct.

Now please write yourself a ‚Äúletter from the future‚Äù. This should be a letter you are writing in the year 2030, to your past self. As the person that you will be in 2030, what role would you think would be appropriate for you in respect to climate change? What would you want to tell yourself in the past? What would you like your past self to do? 
Please spend a bit of time on this task and try to write at least 100 words (5 sentences), or more, if possible.

In this task, we'll give you some information about carbon footprints.

Your carbon footprint is a measure of the greenhouse gas emissions associated with your lifestyle. Greenhouse gas emissions contribute to climate change (global warming). You can help fight climate change by reducing your carbon footprint.

Most of your carbon footprint (about 75%) depends on how you travel, the food you eat, and the energy you use at home.

Today, we'll give you some information about how different actions could reduce an average American's carbon footprint.


The Benefits of Driving Less and Using Electric or Fuel-Efficient Vehicles
 


An average American's gas-powered car produces about 10,141 pounds of carbon emissions every year. 

Reducing fuel consumption by 50% would reduce a person's carbon footprint by about 5,071 pounds in a year. That would save as much carbon as planting 105 trees.

You can reduce your carbon footprint by driving less or switching to a fuel-efficient or electric car.



The Benefits of Reducing Air Travel


The average American generates 844 pounds of carbon emissions each year from domestic air travel alone.

Reducing air travel by 50% would reduce a person's carbon footprint by about 422 pounds. That would save as much carbon as planting 18 trees.

You can reduce your carbon footprint by traveling by train, flying to closer destinations, or choosing airlines that offset their carbon emissions.




The Benefits of Eating More Plants + Fewer Animal Products



Most Americans eat an omnivorous diet, eating a variety of animal and plant products. Eating fewer animal products and more plant products can reduce a person's carbon footprint. Dietary changes don't have to be all or nothing—even small changes matter.

For an average American, replacing red meat (beef and lamb) with chicken would save about 1,062 pounds of carbon each year (22 trees).

Making 50% of meals vegetarian would save about 573 pounds of carbon each year (12 trees).

Switching to a vegetarian diet would save about 1,146 pounds of carbon each year (24 trees).

Switching to a vegan diet would save about 2,006 pounds of carbon each year (41 trees).

 


The Benefits of Powering Your Home with Renewable Energy



For an average American household, the energy used to power and heat a home produces about 12,777 pounds of carbon emissions every year.

Many energy providers let consumers choose to power their homes with renewable energy for a small monthly fee. If 50% of the energy to power a home came from renewable sources, its carbon footprint would be reduced by 6,389 pounds in a year. That would save as much carbon as planting 132 trees.

People can also reduce the carbon footprint of their homes by improving insulation, upgrading to energy-efficient appliances, or installing a heat pump or solar panels.

Write a short comment to describe why this message matters to you personally.

There are many actions people can take to address climate change.

These actions benefit the environment AND they can also benefit YOU and the people you care about.

In the following activity, you’ll be shown 10 actions and brainstorm the personal benefits that YOU might experience by taking these actions. 

For each action, imagine that you start doing this action regularly.

How might YOU benefit immediately, in the moment when doing the action and by doing the action regularly over the next 6 months?

Think about how you might feel, how your life might improve, what you might gain from doing this action, etc.

For each action, your job is to brainstorm as many unique, personal benefits as you can. To help you do that:
 
Focus on YOU—there may be many possible benefits, but focus on how you would benefit personally.

Be creative—focus on the benefits to you across different aspects of your life—your health, well-being, relationships, finances, etc.

Be specific—break down broad benefits (e.g. being healthy) into multiple, specific benefits (e.g. more exercise by walking, healthier heart, lower stress). 

If you think you would experience the same benefits for multiple actions, it's fine to repeat them.

If you already do an action regularly, please describe the benefits you currently experience.

How is care and compassion a key aspect of climate change?


The Earth is rapidly getting hotter due to human activities that produce greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which act like a blanket and trap the sun's heat. With rapidly rising global temperatures the Earth's natural systems will become imbalanced, threatening the well-being of the planet and billions of people.

Care and compassion for others is directly related to addressing climate change.

The impacts of climate change will most severely harm vulnerable people like low- and middle-income families, children, the elderly, and those in low income countries.

Children are especially vulnerable to climate change. Increased air pollution and heat waves can make asthma and other breathing problems worse. Changing weather and droughts lead to food and water shortages, affecting children's health. Elderly people are also at higher risk during extreme heat events, which can cause heat strokes and other health problems.

Show care and compassion and protect vulnerable groups. Reduce your carbon footprint by flying and driving less (and/or using an electric car or public transportation), and shifting your diet to minimize red-meat. Support sustainable policies and renewable energy, like wind and solar, by voting and telling your representatives you care. Volunteer for and donate to organizations that address climate change. These actions show that you care about protecting people now and in the future.

Be the person you want to be and live by your values. Uphold your moral value of care and compassion and approach solutions to climate change in effective and meaningful ways, helping solve this global crisis.

How is equality a key aspect of climate change?


The Earth is rapidly getting hotter due to human activities that produce greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which act like a blanket and trap the sun's heat. With rapidly rising global temperatures the Earth's natural systems will become imbalanced, threatening the well-being of the planet and billions of people.

Equality – ensuring equal opportunities and outcomes for all – is directly related to addressing climate change.

Wealthier nations and high-emission industries have contributed the most to greenhouse gas emissions, benefitting economically but harming the environment. Poorer nations and communities, who have contributed the least to climate change, suffer the most from its impacts, experiencing extreme weather, food and water shortages, and health problems. This is unfair because those who did the least to cause the problem suffer the most. This only makes existing inequalities worse.

Addressing climate change through equality means making sure everyone, no matter their background or socio-economic status, has equal chances to adapt and succeed. This involves investing in strong infrastructure for underserved communities, providing access to clean energy, and ensuring fair distribution of resources and support for climate adaptation. By taking these actions, you can create a fairer world where the benefits and burdens of climate action are shared more equally.

Show how equality matters to you. Reduce your carbon footprint by flying and driving less (and/or using an electric car or public transportation), and shifting your diet to minimize red-meat. Support sustainable policies and renewable energy, like wind and solar, by voting and telling your representatives you care. Volunteer for and donate to organizations that address climate change. These actions show that you care about promoting a just and inclusive society, where everyone has the opportunity to thrive despite the challenges of a changing climate.

Be the person you want to be and live by your values. Uphold your moral value of equality and approach solutions to climate change in effective and meaningful ways, helping solve this global crisis.

How is proportionality a key aspect of climate change?


The Earth is rapidly getting hotter due to human activities that produce greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which act like a blanket and trap the sun's heat. With rapidly rising global temperatures the Earth's natural systems will become imbalanced, threatening the well-being of the planet and billions of people.

Proportionality – the idea that what people put in is what they should get out – is directly related to addressing climate change. This idea is important when thinking about climate change because it emphasizes responsibility and accountability.

Wealthier nations and high-emission industries have contributed the most to greenhouse gas emissions, gaining economic benefits while harming the environment. Poorer nations and communities, who have contributed the least to climate change, suffer the most from its impacts, like extreme weather, food and water shortages, and health problems. This is unfair because those who did the least to cause the problem suffer the most.

Addressing climate change through proportionality means holding companies and countries that pollute the most accountable, ensuring they lead in solving the problem. This includes making policies that require polluters to cut their emissions, fund sustainable development, and help vulnerable communities adapt. By doing this, you make sure those who benefitted the most from industrialization also take responsibility for the consequences.

Show how proportionality matters to you. Reduce your carbon footprint by flying and driving less (and/or using an electric car or public transportation), and shifting your diet to minimize red-meat. Support sustainable policies and renewable energy, like wind and solar, by voting and telling your representatives you care. Volunteer for and donate to organizations that address climate change. These actions show that you care about promoting a fair and just society, where the rewards and burdens of climate action are shared fairly.

Be the person you want to be and live by your values. Uphold your moral value of proportionality and approach solutions to climate change in effective and meaningful ways, helping solve this global crisis.

The Earth is rapidly getting hotter due to human activities that produce greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which act like a blanket and trap the sun's heat. With rapidly rising global temperatures the Earth's natural systems will become imbalanced, threatening the well-being of the planet and billions of people.

Loyalty to one’s group – prioritizing the well-being of your family, community, and country – is directly related to climate change.

Being loyal means protecting the health, security, and prosperity of your loved ones and fellow Americans. Climate change threatens these values with more natural disasters, health risks from pollution, and economic problems.

By fighting climate change, you protect the environment and fulfill your duty to keep our families and communities safe. Loyalty to our country means making sure America stays strong and prosperous despite climate challenges. This means supporting policies for clean energy, reducing emissions, and building sustainable infrastructure. This helps ensure a stable and healthy future for all Americans.

Show how loyalty to your family, community, and country matters to you. Reduce your carbon footprint by flying and driving less (and/or using an electric car or public transportation), and shifting your diet to minimize red-meat. Support sustainable policies and renewable energy, like wind and solar, by voting and telling your representatives you care. Volunteer for and donate to organizations that address climate change. These actions show your commitment to our families and fellow citizens, ensuring everyone can thrive in a safe and sustainable environment.

Be the person you want to be and live by your values. Uphold your moral value of loyalty and approach solutions to climate change in effective and meaningful ways, helping solve this global crisis.

How is respect for authority and tradition a key aspect of climate change?


The Earth is rapidly getting hotter due to human activities that produce greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which act like a blanket and trap the sun's heat. With rapidly rising global temperatures the Earth's natural systems will become imbalanced, threatening the well-being of the planet and billions of people.

Respect for authority and tradition is directly related to addressing climate change.

Strong leadership is crucial in fighting climate change. Respecting authority means supporting environmental experts and leaders who create and enforce policies to reduce climate change, promote sustainable development, and protect our planet.

Traditions of caring for the environment, passed down through generations, remind us of our duty to protect nature. By respecting these traditions, we honor the wisdom of our elders who knew the importance of living in harmony with nature. This respect for authority and tradition helps keep society stable and reinforces our shared responsibility to tackle one of the biggest issues we face today.

Show your respect for authority and tradition. Reduce your carbon footprint by flying and driving less (and/or using an electric car or public transportation), and shifting your diet to minimize red-meat. Support sustainable policies and renewable energy, like wind and solar, by voting and telling your representatives you care. Volunteer for and donate to organizations that address climate change. These actions show your respect for knowledgeable leaders who set environmental rules and for the traditions of caring for the environment and living in harmony with it.

Be the person you want to be and live by your values. Uphold your moral value of respect for authority and tradition and approach solutions to climate change in effective and meaningful ways, helping solve this global crisis.

How are purity and sanctity key aspects of climate change?


The Earth is rapidly getting hotter due to human activities that produce greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which act like a blanket and trap the sun's heat. With rapidly rising global temperatures the Earth's natural systems will become imbalanced, threatening the well-being of the planet and billions of people.

Purity and sanctity – emphasizing the importance of keeping things clean and preserving what is sacred – is directly related to addressing climate change.

Our natural environment, including clean air, water, and forests, is a sacred trust that sustains life. Pollution and excessive use of fossil fuels harm this purity, causing contaminated air and water, deforestation, and rising global temperatures.

Valuing purity means recognizing our responsibility to avoid activities that pollute and degrade the environment. Addressing climate change is not only important for the environment but also a moral duty to uphold the sanctity of our planet.

By reducing pollution, using renewable energy, and conserving forests and water, we honor the sacredness of nature. This reflects deep respect for the environment and the need to keep it clean for the well-being of all living things. Promoting practices that protect and restore the environment ensures that the Earth remains a pure and holy place for future generations.

Show your commitment to the purity and sanctity of nature. Reduce your carbon footprint by flying and driving less (and/or using an electric car or public transportation), and shifting your diet to minimize red-meat. Support sustainable policies and renewable energy, like wind and solar, by voting and telling your representatives you care. Volunteer for and donate to organizations that address climate change. These actions show your desire to maintain a pure and clean environment, free of pollution and contamination.

Be the person you want to be and live by your values. Uphold your moral value of purity and sanctity and approach solutions to climate change in effective and meaningful ways, helping solve this global crisis.

Dear 
,

If you’re skeptical of the government and don’t believe they have your best interests at heart, then it's all the more reason to register to vote.

By staying silent and not registering to vote, you’re allowing the very government you distrust to make critical decisions that affect your life without any pushback. Those in power will continue shaping policies without your input — enforcing laws and making choices that could worsen the very issues you care about.

You’re eligible to vote, which gives you a direct way to challenge the system and push for change. By not registering to vote, you let the government silence you, allowing them to operate unchecked.

Take action — register to vote now and take back control of your future.

Below are six common misperceptions about voter registration.

Myth 1: “Voter registration is a complicated and long process.”
Fact: Voter registration now typically involves a few simple steps online and often takes a matter of minutes.

Myth 2: "If I register to vote, I’ll be called for jury duty."
Fact: Jury duty pools are often compiled from various sources, such as driver’s license records and state ID databases, not just voter registration lists. Registering to vote often has no effect on your chances of being called for jury duty.

Myth 3: "Even if I start the process online, I will need to print and mail my registration form."
Fact: Many states allow you to complete the entire voter registration process online without needing to print or mail anything.

Myth 4: "Online registration is not secure."
Fact: Online voter registration systems are designed with strong security measures to protect your personal information.

Myth 5: "I can’t register online if I don’t have a driver's license."
Fact: While some states require a driver's license or state ID to register online, others accept alternative forms of identification. Check your state’s specific requirements.

Myth 6: "I can’t register online if I have a criminal record."
Fact: Voting rights for individuals with criminal records vary by state. In some states, people with felony convictions can vote once they have completed their sentence, while in others, they may never lose their voting rights. Always check your state’s specific laws.

To register to vote NOW, click on the link on the next page.

More and more people are registering to vote each day! In communities across the country, people just like you are taking the step to ensure their voices are heard.

Young adults, new citizens, and even those who have never voted before are getting registered and making their participation count. As you can see from the following graph, most states saw an increase in voter registration between 2018 and 2022– and this trend continues to this day!

Most States Had an Increase in Voter Registration Rate from 2018 to 2022

By registering to vote, you are joining a growing movement of engaged citizens who are making a difference in their communities. The trend is clear: voter registration is on the rise, and your participation helps create a future where everyone’s voice matters.

One way of evaluating an action is by thinking about whether it would be good or bad for you personally. These pragmatic judgments focus on pros and cons, and take into account the benefit or the harm you may experience if you do something. 
  
A second way of evaluating an action is by thinking about how moral or ethical it is. Rather than thinking about what would benefit you personally, these moral judgments focus on whether or not you ought to do something because it is the right or the wrong thing to do.

Individual and collective action matters and can make our lives better.

At the same time, elected officials often have more power to create change than we do.

For example, if you’re concerned about having clean drinking water, you can take direct action by purchasing a water filter or bottled water. However, elected officials in your community have the power to build water treatment facilities and ensure access to clean water, which can lead to widespread and lasting positive change.

Voting is one way that we get to decide who is in power.

By voting, we can choose officials who reflect our values and petition them to address our concerns.

Got it. It’s flu season, and getting a flu shot at your appt is an easy thing you can do to be healthy!
Be sure to ask for your shot.
[Send if first text generates a response of Y within 2 hours:]
1. Yesterday, did you walk at least 10,000 steps (5 miles)? Text Y for Yes, N for No.
[Send if Q1 generates a response within 2 hours:]

[Send if Q2 generates a response within 2 hours:]

[Send if Q3 generates a response within 2 hours:]
That’s [#] for 3. Those are tough goals to achieve. It’s flu season & getting a flu shot at your upcoming appt is an
easy thing you can do to be healthy!
Be sure to ask for your shot.
[If 2 hours pass with no response to the last Q sent, send:]
It’s flu season & getting a flu shot at your appt is an easy thing you can do to be healthy!

Intervention: Easy health behavior quiz (1 text: 6 pm, 1 d pre-appt)
Content:
John, this is a message from Penn Medicine about your upcoming appointment. Text & data rates apply. Reply stop
to opt out at any time.
You have an appt w/ Dr. Smith on 10/01 @ 11:00am. Want to take a 3 question quiz to assess the health of your
habits? Text Y for Yes, N for No

[If the initial invitation to take the quiz generates a response of N, send.]
Got it. It’s flu season, and getting a flu shot at your appt is an easy thing you can do to be healthy!
Be sure to ask for your shot.

[Send if first text generates a response of Y within 2 hours:]
1. Yesterday, did you walk at least 500 feet? Text Y for Yes, N for No.
[Send if Q1 generates a response within 2 hours:]
2. How about your diet: Did you eat at least two servings of fruits & vegetables in the last week? Text Y or N.

[Send if Q2 generates a response within 2 hours:]
3. And finally, did you sleep at least 6 hours last night? Again, text back Y or N.
[Send if Q3 generates a response within 2 hours:]
That’s [#] for 3. It’s flu season & getting a flu shot at your upcoming appt is an easy thing you can do to be healthy!
Be sure to ask for your shot.
[If 2 hours pass with no response to the last Q sent, send:]
It’s flu season & getting a flu shot at your appt is an easy thing you can do to be healthy!
Be sure to ask for your shot.

Welcome! 
On the next page, you will read a brief article about the United States. 
Please carefully read the article; you may be asked some questions about it later on in the survey. 
Thank you! You can start on the next page. 

The Resilience of the American System
There are many things that make the United States of America unique and special. But one of the biggest factors is that it and its people never abandon the principles that made it great.
In many countries, many times through history, when a crisis happens ‚Äì be it an economic recession or a pandemic or natural disaster ‚Äì people turn on each other and lose faith in the system. Americans have proven robust to this. Through thick and thin, the core of what makes America thrive seems to persist. People might cast doubt or engage in lively debates here and there, but generally, across time, stay faithful to the principles of democracy and civility and respect.
This can be challenging at times, especially with the media and social echo chambers, but time and time again, Americans have proven they stick to what makes them special: faith in the system and trust in each other.

On the following page you will be asked to think about the behavior of political parties and answer questions about such behavior.

How much do you believe a $OUTPARTY opposes this action?

On the next page, you will see information about someone who is a $OUTPARTY. They were asked to consider having a conversation with someone from the opposing party, and write them a message. After you review this information and read their message, you will get a chance to respond to them (and we will actually send them your response!). As you read their message, think about how you would answer their question.

"I am a Republican because they side with many of my important personal beliefs. I think that both sides have some great stances on different issues, but for the issues that are most important to me, I think the Republican party resonates best with me personally. I understand that different people have different beliefs, and these issues vary in importance. This is how we are able to tackle the bigger problems."

In the text box below, please respond to this individual's message. As a reminder, your response will be sent to this person.

This person could be a friend, relative, neighbor, co-worker, or just someone that you know. Please explain why you feel this way about this person.
