Abortion, gun control, and immigration are issues that often divide Democrats and Republicans. On the following pages, we will ask you about your views on these and other political issues.

How do you feel about each of the following issues on a scale from 0 to 100, where 0 represents strongly against and 100 represents strongly for?
Abortion
Gun control
Immigration

Everyone‚Äôs political beliefs are influenced by many factors, including social environments and personal experiences. 
Across fields of research, there is strong support for the idea that our beliefs are influenced by family environment, culture, and personal experience. Even though people often lack control over these factors, they shape the ways in which everyone thinks about and perceives the world. Your life circumstances could have been very different, and those differences would have changed your beliefs and ideas on many issues. 
When you answer each of the following questions, please think about your own political beliefs and how they would have been influenced by factors such as your upbringing, your peers, your community, the media to which you have been exposed, and the historical events you have lived through.

The starting points on the scales below represent the feelings you just indicated about abortion.
While answering the questions below, think about how your life could have gone differently and how your worldview would have been different.
Imagine that you had been raised in the Christian fundamentalist tradition, where abortion is considered morally unacceptable. What do you think your attitude about abortion access would be in those circumstances?
Imagine that you had a younger sister who had become pregnant because she was sexually assaulted by a stranger. What do you think your attitude about abortion access would be in those circumstances?

The starting points on the scales below represent the feelings you just indicated about gun control.
While answering the questions below, think about how your life could have gone differently and how your worldview would have been different.
Imagine that you had been raised in a rural, military family who frequently went hunting and to the shooting range. What do you think your attitude about gun control would be in those circumstances? 
Imagine that you had survived a mass shooting at your high school where the shooter owned the firearm legally. What do you think your attitude about gun control would be in those circumstances?

The starting points on the scales below represent the feelings you just indicated about immigration.
While answering the questions below, think about how your life could have gone differently and how your worldview would have been different.
Imagine that you had a brother who lost his landscaping company due to new immigrants moving into town. What do you think your attitude about immigration would be in those circumstances? 
Imagine that your favorite babysitter growing up was an immigrant who entered the country illegally. What do you think your attitude about immigration would be in those circumstances? 

Below, you can see your combined self-reported political attitudes in the real world, as well as the attitudes you would expect to have in the alternative circumstances you were asked to imagine: 
The gray dot represents your actual views on abortion, gun control, and immigration.
The red dot represents what you think your views would be if you had been exposed to a conservative-leaning environment, and the blue dot represents what you think your views would be if you had been exposed to a liberal-leaning environment. 
The space between the gray dot and the colored dots indicates how much you think the alternative social environments would have influenced your attitudes. This suggests the views held with conviction can be a product of one's environment.

As you have indicated, your beliefs on these topics could easily have been different if your history had been different. 
You are not alone in this. Everyone's beliefs are subject to these same influences. A Democrat might be a Republican if they had faced more conservative-favoring circumstances, and a Republican might be Democrat if they had faced more liberal-favoring circumstances.
Many of your political opponents are good people who have arrived at different beliefs because of the social environments in which they have lived. 
When thinking about your opponents, remember that their beliefs ‚Äî just like yours ‚Äî have been influenced by a variety of circumstances beyond their control.

On the following page, you‚Äôll be asked to read an article. Please read closely, as you‚Äôll be asked several questions about the article afterwards.

James Martherus
Democrats- Let's Support
Peace and Tolerance
It's what we do
If you've been reading the news, you might think Democrats aren't very supportive of Democracy, or even that we believe political violence is acceptable. Social media can seem full of hateful rhetoric between partisans and sensationalized stories about how broken our country is. But I'm a lifelong Democrat and a strong Biden supporter, and let me tell you - that is not who we are.
In fact, President Biden has been very clear about where he stands on violence and hate. In a series of statements made before he took office, President Biden defended our political processes, condemned violence, and encouraged us to be tolerant of those who disagree with us:
"I condemn violence of every kind by anyone, whether on the left or the right... we must not become a country at war with ourselves."
"The work of the next four years must be the restoration of democracy, of decency, honor, respect, the rule of law. Just plain simple decency... Not stoking the flames of hate and chaos...
America is about honor, decency, respect, tolerance. That's who we are."
President Biden is right - good Democrats do not support violence.
We don't support restricting the rights of our fellow Americans. We don't harass or intimidate people who disagree with us. We follow the rules and defend the values that make America great - freedom of speech, freedom of the press, the right to vote, and many other important principles.
My fellow Democrats agree with me. For example, in 2019 political scientists Nathan Kalmoe and Lilliana Mason found that less than 10% of Democrats think violence is a justifiable way to advance political goals. Similarly, they found that at least 90% of Democrats don't think it is ok to break the rules to help their party win.
Let's all follow President's Biden's advice:
"It's time to put away the harsh rhetoric. To lower the temperature. To see each other again. To listen to each other again. To make progress, we must stop treating our opponents as our enemy. We are not enemies. We are Americans."

According to the article, what percentage of ${e://Field/Inparty_Person}s think violence is a justifiable way to advance political goals?
According to the article, ${e://Field/Inparty_Elite} believes we need to come together as a country.

You will now listen to an 8-minute meditation exercise. See if you can find a silent and comfortable place to avoid being interrupted during the meditation and make sure you follow the auditory instructions as closely as possible.
Please press play to start the meditation exercise. 

This is a befriending meditation. So in this sitting, you're cultivating a sense of kindness and friendship towards yourself and others. Acknowledging that no matter how we appear on the outside, all of us can feel fearful, sad, or lonely on the inside. So deliberately taking this time to wish yourself well, and then extending this kindness to others. So taking a few moments now to become settled, reconnecting with a posture that for you embodies a sense of dignity and wakefulness. If you are sitting, checking in with yourself so that the spine is straight, the shoulders relaxed and the head balanced. And coming to focus on the breath, and then expanding attention to the whole body. And when you're ready, bringing kindness and friendship to yourself by silently saying to yourself, may I be safe and free from suffering. May I be as happy and healthy as it is possible for me to be. May I have ease of being. Taking your time, imagining that each phrase is like a pebble dropped down a deep well, dropping each one in turn, and listening for any responses, thoughts, feelings, body sensations. There's no need to judge what arises. This is for you. May I be safe and free from suffering. May I be happy and healthy. May I have ease of being. May I be safe and free from suffering. May I be happy and healthy. May I have ease of being. If you find it difficult to bring any sense of friendship towards yourself, bringing to mind a person or even a pet who loves you or loved you unconditionally. Once you have a clear sense of their love for you, see if you can return to offering this same love to yourself. May I be safe, happy and healthy, ease of being. May I be safe, happy and healthy. Ease of being. Now, at a certain point, bringing to mind a loved one and wishing him or her well in the same way. May they be safe and free from suffering. May they be as happy and as healthy as it is possible for them to be. May they have ease of being. And now choosing a stranger. This may be someone you see regularly, perhaps in the street or on the bus or subway. Someone you recognise, but may not know the name of. Someone you feel neutral about. Although you don't know them, they probably also have a life full of hopes and fears as you have. They too wish to be happy as you do. So keeping them in heart and mind, repeating the phrases and wishing them well. May they be safe and free from suffering. May they be happy and healthy. May they have ease of being. May they be safe and free from suffering. May they be happy and healthy. May they have ease of being. Now, if you choose to extend this meditation further, you might wish to bring to mind someone whom you find difficult. This doesn't have to be the most difficult person in your life. They may be someone you feel a bit distant from, perhaps a person at work or in the family who you're finding rather difficult at the moment. Whomever you choose, now intentionally allowing him or her to be in your heart and mind as best you can, acknowledging that they too may wish or have wished to be happy. May they be safe and free from suffering. May they be happy and healthy. May they have ease of being. May they be safe and free from suffering. May they be happy and healthy. May they have ease of being. And don't worry if there are no feelings of warmth or friendship. It's enough to hold the intention, to incline the mind in this way, and remembering if at any time you feel overwhelmed or drawn away by intense feelings or thoughts, you can always come back to the breath in the body to anchor yourself in the present moment, treating yourself with kindness. Finally, extending loving-kindness to all beings, including your loved ones and strangers and those whom you find difficult. The intention here is to extend love and friendship to all living beings on the planet and remembering that all living beings includes you. May all be free from pain and suffering. May all be happy and healthy. May all of us have ease of being. May all be free from pain and suffering. May all be happy and healthy. May all of us have ease of being. And now coming to the breath in the body. Resting in clear awareness of the present moment. Allowing yourself to be just as you are. Complete.

Instructions: Many people read online stories to keep up with the news. But do they understand the articles they read? We are interested in how people understand media stories about science studies. For this study, please read the following BBC article and then answer a few questions to check your understanding.

Nonviolent protests are twice as likely to succeed as armed conflicts ‚Äì and those engaging a threshold of 3.5% of the population have never failed to bring about change.
There are, of course, many ethical reasons to use nonviolent strategies. But compelling research by Erica Chenoweth, a political scientist at Harvard University, conÔ¨Årms that civil disobedience is not only the moral choice; it is also the most powerful way of shaping world politics ‚Äì by a long way.
Chenoweth performed an extensive review of the literature on civil resistance and social movements from 1900 to 2006 ‚Äì a data set then corroborated with other experts in the Ô¨Åeld. By the end of this process, they had collected data from 323 violent and nonviolent campaigns. And their results were striking.
Looking at hundreds of campaigns over the last century, Chenoweth found that nonviolent campaigns are twice as likely to achieve their goals as violent campaigns. 
Strength in numbers
This was partly the result of strength in numbers. Chenoweth argues that nonviolent campaigns are more likely to succeed because they can recruit many more participants from a much broader demographic. Overall, the nonviolent campaigns attracted around four times as many participants (200,000) as the average violent campaign (50,000).
‚ÄúNumbers really matter for building power in ways that can really pose a serious challenge or threat to entrenched authorities or occupations,‚Äù Chenoweth says ‚Äì and nonviolent protest seems to be the best way to get that widespread support. Chenoweth cites many reasons that nonviolent protests can garner such high levels of support. Perhaps most obviously, violent protests necessarily exclude people who abhor and fear bloodshed, whereas peaceful protesters maintain the moral high ground.
Chenoweth points out that nonviolent protests also have fewer physical barriers to participation. You do not need to be Ô¨Åt and healthy to engage in a strike, whereas violent campaigns tend to lean on the support of physically Ô¨Åt young men. And while many forms of nonviolent protests also carry serious risks ‚Äì just think of China‚Äôs response in Tiananmen Square in 1989 ‚Äì Chenoweth argues that nonviolent campaigns are generally easier to discuss openly, which means that news of their occurrence can reach a wider audience. Violent movements, on the other hand, require a supply of weapons, and tend to rely on more secretive underground operations that might struggle to reach the general population.
By engaging broad support across the population, nonviolent campaigns are also more likely to win support among the police and the military ‚Äì the very groups that the government should be leaning on to bring about order. During a peaceful street protest of millions of people, the members of the security forces may also be more likely to fear that their family members or friends are in the crowd ‚Äì meaning that they fail to crack down on the movement. 
‚ÄúThere are more options for engaging in nonviolent resistance that don‚Äôt place people in as much physical danger, particularly as the numbers grow, compared to armed activity,‚Äù Chenoweth says. ‚ÄúAnd the techniques of nonviolent resistance are often more visible, so that it's easier for people to Ô¨Ånd out how to participate directly, and how to coordinate their activities for maximum disruption.‚Äù
A magic number?
In Chenoweth‚Äôs data set, it was only once the nonviolent protests had achieved that 3.5% threshold of active engagement that success seemed to be guaranteed ‚Äì and raising even that level of support is no mean feat. In the US, it would involve 11 million citizens ‚Äì more than the total population of New York City.
| Once around 3.5% of the whole population has begun to participate actively, success appears to be inevitable.
The fact remains, however, that nonviolent campaigns are the only reliable way of maintaining that kind of engagement.
Chenoweth‚Äôs initial study was Ô¨Årst published in 2011 and their Ô¨Åndings have attracted a lot of attention since. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to overstate how inÔ¨Çuential they have been to this body of research,‚Äù says Matthew Chandler, who researches civil resistance at the University of Notre Dame in Indiana. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs [now] an established truth within the Ô¨Åeld that the nonviolent approaches are much more likely to succeed than violent ones.‚Äù 
David Robson is a senior journalist at BBC Future.

I'm Spencer Cox, your Republican candidate for Utah Governor. And I'm Chris Peterson, your Democratic candidate for Governor. We are currently in the final days of campaigning against each other. But our common values transcend our political differences, and the strength of our nation rests on our ability to see that.
We are both equally dedicated to the American values of democracy, liberty, and justice for all people. We just have different opinions on how to achieve those ideals. But today, we are setting aside those differences to deliver a message that is critical for the health of our nation.
That whether you vote by mail or in person, we will fully support the results of the upcoming presidential election, regardless of the outcome. Although we sit on different sides of the aisle, we are both committed to American civility and a peaceful transition of power. And we hope Utah will be an example to the nation. Because that is what our country is built on. Please stand with us on behalf of our great state and nation. My name's Spencer Cox. And I'm Chris Peterson. And we approve this message.

You might have heard about the echo chambers problem: that people tend to get news that confirms their point of view. Republicans get pro-Republican news, and Democrats get pro-Democrat news. 
You might have also heard some people say we should try to get out of our echo chambers. But it‚Äôs frustrating to do this if people on the other side aren‚Äôt doing the same. 
Well, we‚Äôre going to give you the chance to get someone on "the other side" (a ${e://Field/Outparty_Person}, since you identify as a ${e://Field/Inparty_Person}) out of their echo chamber, in exchange for watching the video on the next page, which was selected by a group of people interested in having Americans exchange articles and videos.

Please take a minute to carefully read the following information about American politics.

The Democratic Party is clearly the dominant force in American politics. Recent victories at the federal level gave Democrats unified control of the federal government for the first time in 30 years. And at the state level, the majority of Americans (almost 55%) live in states with Democratic governors.
According to experts at the nonpartisan Pew Research Center, Millennial and Generation Z voters (those aged 37 and under) are much more Democratic in their party registration and more liberal in their policy preferences. Voters in this age group are more likely to desire a bigger role for government, believe that racism is a problem in the United States, use gender-neutral language, and link human activity to climate change. 
Harvard researcher John Della Volpe has similarly documented the progressivism and enthusiasm of these younger generations continuing to enter the electorate, and recently noted, ‚ÄúWhen you look back at the last 40 years of elections - so that includes when Baby Boomers were in their 20s, Generation X and Millennials - this generation of Zoomers has broken all the turnout records.‚Äù 

Moreover, evidence shows that these younger generations appear to be driving renewed support for organized labor, long a powerful mobilizing force for the Democratic Party.  Recent nonpartisan analysis from Gallup found that, ‚Äúapproval of labor unions is at its highest point since 1965, with nearly four in five (77%) of adults ages 18 through 34 supporting them.‚Äù  A return of broader organized labor subsequently could dramatically expand the political reach of Democrats.
Given that this portion of the electorate will continue to grow as the baby boomers and the silent generation die out, there is reason to believe that the Democratic Party will have sustained electoral success in the future.
In short, the United States is a Democratic-leaning country and will likely continue to be for the foreseeable future.

What percentage of Americans live in states with Democratic governors?

Please take a minute to carefully read the following information about American politics.
The Republican Party is clearly the dominant force in American politics. For the last 40 years, Republicans have consistently held control of Congress and the presidency more often than Democrats. As a result, Republican appointees hold six of the nine seats on the U.S. Supreme Court, 55% of seats in the U.S. Courts of Appeals, and the majority of District Court judgeships. 
According to experts at the nonpartisan Pew Research Center, Republican dominance is even stronger at the state level. Republicans control 30 state legislatures and most governor's mansions. Indeed, Republicans completely control 23 state governments, and even some deep blue states, such as Massachusetts, Maryland, and Vermont, have Republican governors. 
Data analyst David Byler has recently documented the ‚Äúunmatched‚Äù Republican strength in state legislatures, noting, ‚ÄúAfter the 2010 midterm [elections], Republicans were no longer competitive in state capitols ‚Äî they were dominant‚Äù. Not only has this Republican political success at the state level been built over many election cycles, but Byler has been clear in the expectation that this political control will continue into the foreseeable future. 

Moreover, recent evidence suggests a dramatic public shift in political party identification towards the Republican Party. Nonpartisan analysis from Gallup tracked a 14-point swing towards the Republican Party during 2021. This would indicate a profound public transition benefiting the GOP heading into a midterm election year.
Finally, Republicans are likely to make gains in the House and the Senate as they head into a midterm election with a languishing Biden presidency, bogged down by the continuation of the pandemic, the bungling of the withdrawal from Afghanistan, and rampant inflation. 
In short, the United States is a Republican-leaning country and will likely continue to be for the foreseeable future.

Over the last 40 years, which political party has tended to control Congress and the presidency most?
How many state legislatures in the U.S. are controlled by the Republican Party?
Based on historical patterns and public opinion polls, what do experts predict for the 2022 midterm elections?

Thank you for taking part in our study. On the next page you will be asked to watch a brief video (4.30 mins). After watching the video you will then be asked a question about what you have just seen.

In the US, much is made of the social issues that divide liberals and conservatives, but far less attention is given to the shared economic interests and concerns that unite regular working Americans.
On top of decades of wage stagnation and rising levels of debt, automation and foreign trade are now stripping away millions of U.S. jobs, leaving many Americans one paycheck away from a financial emergency. Whether liberal or conservative, the we're-all-in-this-together sentiment really does apply to most Americans. That is, with the exception of the super-rich. The class of the super-rich may pay lip service to their Democrat or Republican allegiance,
Yet, they share very little in common with their fellow Democrats and Republicans in the working and middle class. In fact, they have far more in common with their wealthy political counterparts.
Together they invest in the same companies, attend the same lavish events, and send their children to the same elite schools and colleges. In the US today, then, it is wealth, not political orientation, that divides Americans in terms of their challenges and life outcomes. To take one striking example of this, the super-rich actually get more years of life than the rest of us.
Comparing the top 1% of household income earners to the bottom 50%, people in the top 1% live an average of 8.5 years longer than those in the bottom 50%. But increased life expectancy is just one of many examples of how the super-rich increasingly share a very different fate than the rest of us.
In 2020, when unemployment hit record lows and many ordinary Americans were struggling to provide for themselves and their family, U.S. billionaires became richer. Substantially richer. Their collective wealth increased by about $1.2 trillion from January 2020 to April 2021. Looking back further, over the past 40 years, the top 1% have captured a greater and greater share of total U.S. income, leaving less and less for the millions of Americans in the working and middle class.
Of course, being financially successful is by no means a bad thing in and of itself, but time and time again wealthy Americans on both the left and right avoid paying their fair share. Many of us have heard stories of how CEOs of large corporations pay less in taxes than their minimum wage employees.
The problem doesn't end there, though. The super-rich use their extensive wealth to anonymously donate large sums to political parties, often not to further the goals of liberal or conservative Americans, but to further the goals of themselves and their super-rich friends. Both Democratic and Republican politicians alike receive millions in so-called dark money from Wall Street, Silicon Valley, and other powerful industries, who wish to shape legislation to further their own business interests.
The super-rich don't just influence the law in the US, they're often above it too. Indeed, as we saw in the 2008 financial crisis, when industry leaders in the finance sector commit crimes, crimes that destabilize the entire economy and push the country into a deep recession, they don't get punished for it. In fact, several CEOs responsible for this crisis went on to pay themselves huge bonuses just months later. The super-rich are prospering from the misfortune of regular Americans.
Watching the news, it can be easy to see the country as being split along political lines, but in fact most ordinary Americans simply wish to be able to work hard, and be free to live a long, healthy, and happy life. Unfortunately, the ability to rise up the economic ladder is more difficult than many realize.
Research has shown that an American born to a household in the bottom 20% of earnings has less than an 8% chance of reaching the top 20% by the time they're an adult. But this isn't just a natural quirk of the modern economy. Wealthy elites are contributing to this oppression. In March 2019, for instance, federal prosecutors revealed that 33 wealthy parents had paid large sums to get their children into elite universities, including Yale and Stanford, without actually achieving the necessary grades.
Not content with just climbing the economic ladder themselves, they are securing their own privilege by pulling the ladder away from hard-working Americans. For many of these top earners, politics is being used as a tool to pursue self-interest, not political ideology.
Looking forward then, ordinary Americans on the left and right in fact share a common cause, to ensure that the super-rich are no longer able to cheat the system, at the expense of hard-working Americans. To do so, will often require looking beyond divisive social issues, and focusing instead on the goals so many Americans share, improving career opportunities, health, education, and happiness for ourselves, our friends, and our families.

Tim leans Democratic because of his stance on guns. He says, "I am anti-gun because I had a friend who was shot and murdered by a gun. The person who killed him was able to get that gun without having a proper background check. Gun laws need to be changed."

This is why I feel that people need to take this seriously, WEAR your dang mask, it's not about taking away your freedom, it's about saving your dang life."

In a previous survey of Republicans in September 2020, we asked them a variety of questions regarding their preferences. Recall that this was before the tests of the COVID-19 vaccines were completed and they were approved for the general public. It was also before the 2020 presidential election, which was held on November 3, 2020. 
On the following pages, we are going to ask you to predict their answers to these questions. For the following questions, please indicate how you think a TYPICAL REPUBLICAN SURVEY RESPONDENT WOULD ANSWER.

Remember, we asked this question of Republicans in a survey in September 2020, before tests of the COVID-19 vaccine were completed and before the 2020 Presidential Election.
The U.S. Presidential Election is on November 3, 2020. Estimates from scientists suggest that in order to ensure the vaccine is 100% safe and does not have later side effects, trials will need to continue until January 1, 2021. On the other hand, political analysts suggest that the announcement of a successful vaccine could go a long way in boosting Trump‚Äôs re-election odds. Scientists believe that there is a possible risk of releasing the vaccine before the trials complete, as there may be unanticipated side effects for at least some groups of Americans. At the earliest, side effects would be revealed at least two weeks after vaccine administration.      
Given the information above, would you prefer the vaccine is released on November 1, 2020 or January 1, 2021? 
Below, we'd like you to estimate how you think REPUBLICAN SURVEY RESPONDENTS answered in September 2020. The numbers must add to 100 percent.

For the following question, please indicate how you think a TYPICAL REPUBLICAN SURVEY RESPONDENT answered in September 2020, before the 2020 elections in November 2020. 
As of September 2020, the COVID-19 case toll in the state of Washington stands at approximately 80,000. Most analysts agree that the number of total coronavirus cases will influence Democratic Governor Jay Inslee's chances of being re-elected in the November 3, 2020 election. Democratic Governor Jay Inslee will be running for re-election against Republican nominee Loren Culp. ‚Ä®When Republicans took our survey in September 2020, which option do you think they were most likely to choose? 

It turns out, partisans tend to over-estimate how willing members of the other party are to make trade-offs like those you just saw. 
In our survey in September 2020, we asked 208 Republicans to make the choices you just saw. We also asked 191 Democrats to predict their answers.
For the vaccine question, while only 24% of Republicans preferred a rushed vaccine before the election, Democrats thought that over 66% of Republicans would have this preference. 

For the question about trading off covid cases to stop a Democratic Governor's re-election, the average Republican's answer was 110,000 cases and 70% chance of the Democratic Governor's re-election. Democrats tended to think that the answer would be 150,000 cases and 30% chance for the Democratic Governor's re-election. In fact, far more Republicans chose the minimum number of cases (even if it meant ensuring the Democratic Governor would be re-elected) than the maximum number of cases (which ensured the Democratic Governor would not be re-elected).    ‚Ä®In this study and many others, our research has found that partisans tend to over-estimate how willing members of the other group are to trade-off material harm in order to get the upper hand on our group.   ‚Ä®On the following two pages, we've copied some responses that Republicans wrote after we asked them these questions. Please take a few moments to read and consider them carefully.

Quotes from Republicans for why they wouldn't rush an unsafe vaccine before the election ‚Ä®"Having a vaccine that works is more important than who gets elected, although I would much prefer a Republican over a Democrat." ‚Ä®"People's lives are a lot more important than politics." ‚Ä®"What I know is that I am sick of seeing both sides fight like they are children in a school yard. They are there for the good of the people." 

Quotes from Republicans for why they wouldn't want extra COVID cases just to hurt a Democratic Governor's re-election chances‚Ä®"I wouldn't even take a chance on lowering their chance at winning if it meant more people getting sick."‚Ä®"Do I want COVID cases to go up just to get another person elected? Can't I just want the lowest number of cases possible?" ‚Ä®"I identify as a Republican, but I wouldn't risk more people getting covid just so a Republican can win an election. If it means that a Democrat wins, so be it."

They just shut down somebody else completely. They just have this wall up and they don't even want to hear it. President Donald J. Trump. I voted for Joe Biden. Biden, for sure. If you want to just keep it as Republican, we can just keep it simple, but... I voted for Donald Trump. Biden and Harris. I voted for Joe Biden. You just had to stay silent. I was afraid to put a Trump sign in my yard. I did not vote in the 2020 election. Biden. Biden. Joe Biden. I voted for Donald Trump.
We began with immigration. I'm a DACA recipient. It's safer to have closed borders. Every single human has the right to succeed. Few people are like, just leave the door wide open. 100% of legal immigrants to be allowed to come into this country legally.
Members of each party were asked to rate their own views on immigration based on a general preference for closed or open borders. In our survey, zero means keeping all borders completely open to all migrants, and 100 means keeping all borders completely closed to all migrants. Maybe, like, 25? I would be a 10, let's say. I would say that I lie at 40. Like, 20. 80, 85. About a 40.
I would say 15 on that scale. We then asked them to answer the same question. However, estimating how the average member of the other party would rate their view. 100. 10. 100. They would probably think that me as a Democrat is a zero. In that 10 to 20 range. Zero. Probably 90 to 100.
Oh, they'd probably think that I was, like, zero. Ten, honestly. And finally, we shared the results of the two questions. That's amazing. Oh. There's so much more overlap than I think we realize. We also asked Republicans and Democrats to rate how evolved they think members of the other party would see them. Oh, at a zero. And then how evolved they actually view members of the other party themselves. Like, to say that they're less than human?
I wouldn't put anyone who disagrees with my views as subhuman. They're just as human as I am. I would also put Democrats at 100. They are human beings also. For Republicans? In reality, Republicans and Democrats viewed each other about twice as evolved and civilized as members of each party predated. Yep. What we see when we turn on the TV and what we read on social media does not depict that.

The upcoming activity includes audio narration to enhance your experience. On each page, click the play button that appears at the top of the screen to begin the narration (see example image below):

Welcome   
Americans across the political spectrum are uncomfortable with the negative tone in our politics these days. They remember a time when Americans had real respect for each other, no matter what their politics were.
Today, we‚Äôd like to share the feelings of some of those Americans with you, as well as some information about why this tone of mutual respect has been replaced by so much rage, disrespect, and even hatred in recent years. Most of the information we‚Äôll share with you has been hidden from the American public. But this is information that every American should have. Our goal is not to tell you what you should believe. We are simply interested in what you think. Later, we will ask you to share your thoughts with us.
To start, we'd like you to read two short statements that portray how many Americans have been feeling.
By the way: In these statements, we won‚Äôt mention the specific political party a person supports. People have told us that this allows them to focus on what the person is saying, instead of being distracted by what ‚Äúteam‚Äù the person is supposedly on.
 
Story 1 of 2
Here is what one person said:
‚ÄúLately, it feels like our country is becoming so divided and angry. I feel like it‚Äôs important for me to keep up with the news. But then I don‚Äôt like how it makes me feel. It just feels like something has changed in how Americans talk to each other lately‚Äîand not for the better."

Story 2 of 2 
Here is what another person said:
"It seems like when I watch the news and scroll through social media now, Americans are all lumped into one bucket or another. You‚Äôre either a Democrat or a Republican, and the news just assumes that everyone on one side is supposed to hate everyone on the other side. At first, I kind of went along with it. But lately, I realized that I‚Äôve been spending too much time mad at other Americans. I still disagree with [people who support the other party], but I don‚Äôt see them as my enemy anymore. I think it would be good for the country if we spent more time finding things we can agree on‚Äîthings that we all know would help the country.‚Äù

Why Does the Country Feel So Divided? (Page 1 of 2)
How common are stories like these? A recent survey by a non-partisan research group found that two-thirds of Americans are tired of political arguing. They just want people to start listening to each other and working together to solve the problems we all face as a country. The study calls these Americans the exhausted majority, which means most people are tired and wish we focused on the goals that we all share.
But we wondered: How much of the hostility and disrespect in our politics these days is manufactured by the news and social media?
By the way: Everyone can read the facts we will present and make up their own minds about them. Throughout this activity, we'll include references to our sources.
Sources‚Ä®1. Hawkins, S., Yudkin, D., Juan-Torres, M., & Dixon, T. (2019). Hidden tribes: A study of America's polarized landscape.

Why Does the Country Feel So Divided? (Page 2 of 2)
In recent years, the news business has shifted away from its mission of informing the public. It now places much more emphasis on news stories that make us angry at the people who disagree with us. They do this because they know that outrage grabs our attention much more than regular, ‚Äújust-the-facts‚Äù news. Making people believe that their fellow citizens are a threat to the American way of life helps news and social media companies attract bigger audiences and sell more ads.
Sources‚Ä®1. Berry, J. M., & Sobieraj, S. (2013). The outrage industry: Political opinion media and the new incivility. Oxford University Press.‚Ä®2. Taibbi, M. (2019). Hate Inc.: Why today‚Äôs media makes us despise one another (1st ed.). OR Books.

Frustrated Reporters are Revealing an Ugly Truth about the News Business 
Recently, a growing number of news reporters have become uncomfortable with pressure from their bosses to produce divisive new stories. So uncomfortable that they‚Äôve decided to come forward and tell the public the truth.
One example comes from Matt Taibbi. He is a reporter who spent decades covering national politics for mainstream news outlets. In his book, Hate, Inc., Taibbi reveals how news media executives developed a business plan based on turning Americans against each other. They did this to keep people watching.
In Taibbi's own words:
"We [reporters] were [always] encouraged to aim content at your outrage center... [The idea was not just to make you mad, but to keep you mad, whipped up in a state of devotional anger... The political impact of all this was that the news watcher [...] became
more addicted to the experience of being outraged."
-Matt Taibbi, Hate Inc.
Sources‚Ä®1. Taibbi, M. (2019). Hate Inc.: Why today‚Äôs media makes us despise one another (1st ed.). OR Books.‚Ä®Do your own research (additional sources):‚Ä®2. Berry, J. M., & Sobieraj, S. (2013). The outrage industry: Political opinion media and the new incivility. Oxford University Press.‚Ä®3. Ripley, A. (2021). High conflict: Why we get trapped and how we get out. Simon & Schuster, Incorporated.

How the News Media Tries to Divide Us (Page 1 of 2)
How exactly did the news media come up with this ‚Äúdivide-and-conquer‚Äù strategy?
By the late 2010s, virtually every commercial news organization had chosen a ‚Äúside‚Äù‚Äîthey produced content specifically for Republicans or specifically for Democrats. They already understood that people watch more news during national emergencies‚Äîlike 9/11, for example. 
They figured out that if they portrayed the ‚Äúother side‚Äù as a threat to the American way of life, they could make every single day feel like a new national emergency and keep millions of people glued to their coverage.
Sources
1. Taibbi, M. (2019). Hate Inc.: Why today‚Äôs media makes us despise one another (1st ed.). OR Books.
Do your own research (additional sources):
2. Berry, J. M., & Sobieraj, S. (2013). The outrage industry: Political opinion media and the new incivility. Oxford University Press.
3. Ripley, A. (2021). High conflict: Why we get trapped and how we get out. Simon & Schuster, Incorporated.

How the News Media Tries to Divide Us (Page 2 of 2)
Reporters were even encouraged to turn entirely non-partisan news stories into ‚Äúcrises‚Äù and make it seem like the other party was entirely at fault. 
"The hyper-intense tone [of news stories] was a deliberate strategy," the journalist, Taibbi, went on to explain. Most of the anger Americans feel for supporters of the opposing political party comes largely from "people like me, pushing your buttons for cash." 
And the influx of cash was unprecedented.
Sources‚Ä®1. Taibbi, M. (2019). Hate Inc.: Why today‚Äôs media makes us despise one another (1st ed.). OR Books.‚Ä®Do your own research (additional sources):‚Ä®2. Berry, J. M., & Sobieraj, S. (2013). The outrage industry: Political opinion media and the new incivility. Oxford University Press.‚Ä®3. Ripley, A. (2021). High conflict: Why we get trapped and how we get out. Simon & Schuster, Incorporated.

Tell us your thoughts: What struck you most about the information we have shared with you so far? Please jot down one or two things in the box below.

How Big are Our Differences, Really? (Page 1 of 2)
Most Americans who support different political parties actually have much more in common and feel more positively toward each other than the news makes it seem.
How do we know this? The same non-partisan research organization we mentioned earlier actually asked Americans how they felt. They found that Democrats and Republicans actually agree with each other much more than either group thinks. 
Here are just a couple of examples: 
They agree more on gun control laws‚Äîfor instance, more Democrats are supportive of the right to keep and bear arms than Republicans have been led to believe. They also agree more on immigration‚Äîfor instance, more Republicans support welcoming immigration policies than Democrats have been led to believe.
Sources
1. Yudkin, D., Hawkins, S., & Dixon, T. (2019). The perception gap: How false impressions are pulling Americans apart.
2. Moore-Berg, S. L., Ankori-Karlinsky, L. O., Hameiri, B., & Bruneau, E. (2020). Exaggerated meta-perceptions predict intergroup hostility between American political partisans. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 117, 14864-14872.

How Big are Our Differences, Really?  (Page 2 of 2)
Most Americans don‚Äôt realize how much they have in common because the news media consistently focuses on and exaggerates the voices of the most extreme partisans on each side.
One consequence of this is that we come to think of those extreme voices as representing the average Democrat or Republican. Of course, this has led to skewed perceptions, on both sides, of what people who support the opposing party are really like. 
And many Americans are also frustrated to have their side represented in such extreme and often negative ways. For example, some fringe people on both sides may say or do outrageous or unacceptable things, but that doesn‚Äôt represent who most of us really are.
Sources
1. Yudkin, D., Hawkins, S., & Dixon, T. (2019). The perception gap: How false impressions are pulling Americans apart.
2. Moore-Berg, S. L., Ankori-Karlinsky, L. O., Hameiri, B., & Bruneau, E. (2020). Exaggerated meta-perceptions predict intergroup hostility between American political partisans. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 117, 14864-14872.
3. Taibbi, M. (2019). Hate Inc.: Why today‚Äôs media makes us despise one another (1st ed.). OR Books.

In the Words of Real Americans
We hope that you have found the information we shared to be interesting and worthwhile. To end our session, we want to hear the voices of real Americans like yourself. Please answer the following two questions in 1-2 sentences each:
First, what was the most important thing you learned from the information we shared with you today?
Second, what are the main ways, if any, that the information you learned today has changed your perceptions of the average supporter of the other political party? 
In addition, if you interact with supporters of the other party in your daily life, what is one small gesture of good will or one small courtesy you could extend as a way to help restore a climate of mutual respect in American public life?

So you say your religion is being hijacked? There are people that are doing outrageous things in the name of Islam. And what I always, the question I always ask is when other people are committing these atrocities, do we do that to other faiths? This fixation on blaming an entire faith community for the acts of a few.

I had someone today tell me, but listen, you can't disaffiliate yourself with these people. They say they believe in Allah. Don't you believe in Allah too? Well, the Westboro Baptist Church, they're Christians. KKK was lynching people in this country. They were also Christians. This fixation and obsession with asking Muslims to condemn all acts of terrorism,

And saying that it represents all of Islam, for me, is ridiculous. It wears me out. It takes a toll on our community. You talk about this very personally, and I know you've talked about it off-air, maybe you haven't talked about it on-air. You get a lot of comments when you come on the air. What do people say to you online? They talk about where you dress, what you're wearing.

They attack my faith and they tell me that I'm a vicious person, my religion's violent, I should go back to Saudi Arabia, that I worship a faith that says that we should be killing infidels.

attacking me personally and saying not very nice things to me, but also the expectations that, where are you today? There was an attack. Where's your condemnation? As if, you know, I'm waiting for things to happen and for me to condemn and apologize. And is that expected from other faith communities, from other people that represent other ethnic, other racial groups? And I think it wears down the community, these expectations for us to condemn the acts of few people out of 1.5 billion Muslims in this world.

How can Muslims contribute to the positive part of the conversation, do you think? The Muslims are out there condemning. Muslims are out there contributing to their communities. Muslims are citizens, whether it be of France, of the United States, of Australia, wherever it is. It's the double standards of some of the mainstream media.

I'm a blogger, a filmmaker and a butcher, and I'll explain how these identities come together. It started four years ago when a friend and I opened our first Ramadan fast at one of the busiest mosques in New York City. Crowds of men with beards and skullcaps were swarming the streets. It was an FBI agent's wet dream.

But being a part of this community, we knew how welcoming this space was. For years, I'd seen photos of this space being documented as a lifeless and cold monolith, much like the stereotypical image painted of the American Muslim experience. Frustrated by this myopic view, my friend and I had this crazy idea.

Let's break our fast at a different mosque in a different state each night of Ramadan and share those stories on a blog. We called it 30 Mosques in 30 Days, and we drove to all the 50 states and shared stories from over 100 vastly different Muslim communities, ranging from the Cambodian refugees in the L.A. projects to the black Sufis living in the woods of South Carolina. What emerged was a beautiful and complicated portrait of America.

The media coverage forced local journalists to revisit their Muslim communities. But what was really exciting was seeing people from around the world being inspired to take their own 30 Moss journey. There were even these two NFL athletes that took a sabbatical from the league to do so. And as 30 Moss was blossoming around the world, I was actually stuck in Pakistan working on a film.

My co-director, Umar, and I were at a breaking point with many of our friends on how to position the film. The movie is called These Birds Walk, and it is about wayward street kids who are struggling to find some semblance of family. We focused on the complexities of youth and family discord, but our friends kept on nudging us to comment on drones and target killings to make the film more relevant, essentially reducing these people who have entrusted us with their stories into sociopolitical symbols.

Of course, we didn't listen to them, and instead, we championed the tender gestures of love and headlong flashes of youth. The agenda behind our cinematic immersion was only empathy, an emotion that's largely deficient from films that come from our region of the world.

And as Deedsbirds Walk played at film festivals and theaters internationally, I finally had my feet planted at home in New York. And with all the extra time and still no real money, my wife tasked me to cook more for us. And whenever I'd go to the local butcher to purchase some halal meat, something felt off.

For those that don't know, halal is a term used for meat that is raised and slaughtered humanely, following very strict Islamic guidelines. Unfortunately, the majority of halal meat in America doesn't rise to the standard that my faith calls for. The more I learned about these unethical practices, the more violated I felt, particularly because businesses from my own community were the ones taking advantage of my orthodoxy.

So with emotions running high and absolutely no experience in butchery, some friends and I opened a meat store in the heart of the East Village Fashion District. We call it Honest Chops, and we're reclaiming halal by sourcing organic, humanely raised animals and by making it accessible and affordable to working-class families. There's really nothing like it in America. The unbelievable part is actually that 90 percent of our in-store customers are not even Muslim.

For many, it is their first time interacting with Islam on such an intimate level. So all these disparate projects ...

are the result of a restlessness. They are a visceral response to the businesses and curators who work hard to oversimplify my beliefs and my community. And the only way to beat the machine is to play by different rules. We must fight with an inventive approach, with the trust, with the access, with the love that only we can bring. We must unapologetically reclaim our beliefs in every moving image, in every cut of meat.

Because if we whitewash our stories for the sake of mass appeal, not only will we fail, but we will be trumped by those with more money and more resources to tell our stories. But the call for creative courage is not for novelty or relevance. It is simply because our communities are so damn unique and so damn beautiful. They demand us to find uncompromising ways to be acknowledged and respected. Thank you.

Let me ask you, Reza, this amazing constitutional right to freedom of expression, which they don't have institutionalized here in Britain. Do you think that this is what's led to this very polarized discussion in the U.S.? And you're right in the middle of it.

Well, I think it's a little bit more complicated than that. Partly it has to do with the fact that only about 1% of the population of the United States is Muslim. And according to polls, less than 40% of Americans claim to have ever met a Muslim. And that's certainly quite different in a place like the UK, which is much more multicultural, has a lot larger Muslim, a lot older Muslim presence than we have here in the United States. And frankly, that's an incredibly important factor because relationships has a huge

huge role to play in sort of dismissing the kinds of blanket statements and generalizations that have become such a part of the rhetoric about Islam in the modern world today.

Rosa, let me just ask you, because I want to play a clip of an interview that you actually had on CNN. CNN that's only shown in the United States. And whereas the majority of American Muslims identify themselves as moderate and tolerant, the impression that's given on the news shows is quite the opposite. Let's just listen to this clip for a second.

Your point is that Muslim countries are not to blame. There is nothing particular. There's no common thread in Muslim countries. You can't paint with a broad brush that somehow their justice system or Sharia law or what they're doing in terms of stoning and female mutilation is different than in other countries like Western countries.

Stoning and mutilation and those barbaric practices should be condemned and criticized by everyone. The actions of individuals and societies and countries like Iran, like Pakistan, like Saudi Arabia must be condemned because they don't belong in the 21st century. But to say Muslim countries as though Pakistan and Turkey are the same, as though Indonesia and Saudi Arabia are the same,

So Reza, that was a month ago, you on CNN, and this debate is still being had, that this sort of broad brush is being painted. Do you think some of it is because there is very little foreign or international news on American television these days? People don't really have a broad sort of pool to look into.

I think that has a large part to do with it. I think it's inherent to American media. Look, someone once said that if the only thing you knew about...
